commit_message:
ensure DatabaseFixture removes db on cleanup

The DatabaseFixture was previously just ensuring that tests which used
it had a clean database when they started. It did not ensure there was
no working database around when it wasn't being used, so tests which
leaked into the database might pass even if they were listed as a

subject: Create resource cache upon creation
commit_message:
Create resource cache upon creation

Currently, the keystone providers ignore the output of the create
command even though it provides much-needed information. This is a
problem because if during the course of the puppet run that
information is needed again, it must make another API request for it.
This is especially problematic with the neutron providers, which
instead of looking up the information via the API, look it up in the
catalog. Since a keystone resource does not specify its ID upon
creation, it reports it as nil, causing the neutron providers to
silently fail when they need the ID of a keystone resource.

This patch corrects the problem by saving the output from the create
command in the @instance variable so that it is known to that
resource and can be retrieved by other resources.

Alternative to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154812/

Change-Id: I2090f5f4a94a6ae21bf71ac0f1b33caaa602e0bc

subject: Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator
commit_message:
Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator

We use @reverts_task_state everywhere in the compute manager and we
ensure that 'instance' is a parameter to the decorator method via
@utils.expects_func_args('instance'), however, that only ensures there
is an instance argument, not that it's in args or kwargs (either is fine
for what expects_func_args checks).

The reverts_task_state decorator can get a KeyError when checking
kwargs['instance'] and fail to revert the task_state on the instance,
which can leave us in a bad state where non-admins can't delete the
instance if the task_state is not None (and the reset-state API is
admin-only).

This fixes the KeyError in the decorator by normalizing the args/kwargs
list into a single dict that we can pull the instance from.

Also adds a warning log if we fail the instance update since it
shouldn't happen and we want to know if it does because of the
aforementioned problems with deleting orphaned instances.

There isn't a specific unit test added for this since moving
kwargs['instance'] above the try/except in reverts_task_state makes a
lot of tests fail already if you don't have the normalize code.

Closes-Bug: #1423952

Change-Id: I70f464120c798422f9a3d601b7cdf3b0a8320690
(cherry picked from commit c43f2b0d708f0f4b37850d2917c0abcc13b8789b)

Repair ArchiveTestCase to pass in all cases

ArchiveTestCase runs the archive_deleted_rows() routine
with a fixed limit of rows, and expects it to affect
specific tables which are then tested.  Since
this routine normally scans through all tables
in the model non-deterministically, it often locates
tables that also have archivable rows in them which are not
the target of the test, and then failing to delete
the expected rows since it only deletes up to a
fixed number.

This patch proposes one quick way to resolve, which is
to limit the tables that are considered by the routine
within the span of unit tests.   This might not be
the approach Nova devs want to take; another approach
may be to add more verbose inspection facilities
to archive_deleted_rows() so that the work it performs
can be tested in a more fine-grained way.

subject: Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator
commit_message:
Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator

We use @reverts_task_state everywhere in the compute manager and we
ensure that 'instance' is a parameter to the decorator method via
@utils.expects_func_args('instance'), however, that only ensures there
is an instance argument, not that it's in args or kwargs (either is fine
for what expects_func_args checks).

The reverts_task_state decorator can get a KeyError when checking
kwargs['instance'] and fail to revert the task_state on the instance,
which can leave us in a bad state where non-admins can't delete the
instance if the task_state is not None (and the reset-state API is
admin-only).

This fixes the KeyError in the decorator by normalizing the args/kwargs
list into a single dict that we can pull the instance from.

Also adds a warning log if we fail the instance update since it
shouldn't happen and we want to know if it does because of the
aforementioned problems with deleting orphaned instances.

There isn't a specific unit test added for this since moving
kwargs['instance'] above the try/except in reverts_task_state makes a
lot of tests fail already if you don't have the normalize code.

Closes-Bug: #1423952

Change-Id: I70f464120c798422f9a3d601b7cdf3b0a8320690

subject: Enable offline compression for resource files
commit_message:
Enable offline compression for resource files

The default value for OFFLINE_COMPRESS is False, as per the Django
compressor docs. When using offline compression, it seems that different
request contexts may generate different CSS files with different names
by way of the SCSS generator. When the HTML is returned to the browser,
the CSS filename referenced will only exist on the node that received
the initial request and generated the CSS file locally, however in a
load-balanced scenario with multiple Horizon instances, the actual HTTP
request for the CSS file has a n-1/n chance of hitting another node that
may be lacking that file, resulting in an unstyled page.

Changing the OFFLINE_COMPRESS value to True enables Django to use the
pre-generated list of resources -- created via the manage.py compress
command -- which is stored in a manifest.json file and should be the
same name/content across the instances since it's not varying by request
context like during online compression.

Change-Id: Iccb9b8cd30b7a61435f9ccc813c4032a24cbe52a
Closes-Bug: #1423783

>>> from glance.common import config  # we do this importing order for

subject: Ensure a hypervisor is only managed by a single compute host
commit_message:
Ensure a hypervisor is only managed by a single compute host

Nova does not support a hypervisor managed by more than 1 compute
host. This change makes that lack of support explicit by causing Nova
to raise an exception when attempting to create a compute node which
violates it. If the compute driver reports all nodes at startup, as
the VMware driver does, and Ironic can do, this will cause a
misconfigured Nova to fail to start. This is preferrable to allowing
the system to run, which will require manual cleanup and may result in
data loss.

Specifically, if the compute driver reports a hypervisor node from
get_available_nodes(), Nova assumes that all instances associated with
that node will also have the same compute host. This assumption is
pervasive, and violating it breaks a large number of things. The bug
below notes that the evacuation cleanup code will cause all instances
running on the hypervisor to be erroneously deleted. It will also
prevent all periodic tasks from running correctly.

There are currently only 2 drivers which report a hypervisor identity
different to the compute host: VMware and Ironic. No other drivers
are affected by this change.

Note that this change is not related to support for multiple
hypervisors per compute host. It relates to a single hypervisor being
accidentally managed by multiple compute hosts, which is not
supported.

subject: Eventlet green threads not released back to pool
commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection. Because of this problem, the green thread is not released
back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Icehouse backport note: socket_timeout was dropped, it was introduced
in 0.14[*] and Icehouse eventlet lower bound is 0.13

[*] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/7d4916f01462de09cb58853d9de2e85777c2ad5b

SecurityImpact

subject: Add minimal diversity requirement for new projects
commit_message:
Add minimal diversity requirement for new projects

In the incubation/graduation model contributor diversity was a
requirement for graduation, since one of the goals of incubation was to
increase contributor diversity.

But with the big tent model, where there are significantly more
projects in OpenStack, and we don't pick 'winners' I don't think its
realistic to assume joining OpenStack guarantees a growth in contributor
diversity.

At the same time one of OpenStack's big attractions is community driven
projects where no single company overwhelmingly dominates.

Instead of the previous diversity requirement (Project must have a large and
diverse team of contributors) and a lower bar to at least make sure new
projects aren't overwhelmingly dominated by a single company.

Note: this raises the bar for projects to join OpenStack, but hopefully
in a way that aligns with the big tent initiative.

subject: Split swift-storage element into separate swift service elements
commit_message:
Split swift-storage element into separate swift service elements

At the moment all swift storage services (acc/cont/obj) are located in the
same element and as a result, any nodes that are used for swift storage
will have all services running on them. However, it would be of benefit to
have the option to split these service accross different nodes. For example,
depending on what type of hardware is being utilised it can often be more
efficient splitting the object services from the account and container services.

This change splits the swift-storage element into four separate elements:

    - swift-storage
    - swift-account
    - swift-container
    - swift-object

Swift storage is now a less loaded element with common storage services and
tools such as rsync and recon. Each other element contains their own separate
packages, configuration files and process start-ups. The three extra elements
also have an element-dependancy on the swift-storage.

Note that I have added the three extra elements in the element-dependancy file
of swift-storage so that the devtest scripts do not break as a result of this
change. If this change is accepted, I will edit devtest_overcloud.py in the
tripleo-incubator environment to include the three extra elements and then
remove the extra elements dependancy introduced here.

subject: Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator
commit_message:
Fix kwargs['instance'] KeyError in @reverts_task_state decorator

We use @reverts_task_state everywhere in the compute manager and we
ensure that 'instance' is a parameter to the decorator method via
@utils.expects_func_args('instance'), however, that only ensures there
is an instance argument, not that it's in args or kwargs (either is fine
for what expects_func_args checks).

The reverts_task_state decorator can get a KeyError when checking
kwargs['instance'] and fail to revert the task_state on the instance,
which can leave us in a bad state where non-admins can't delete the
instance if the task_state is not None (and the reset-state API is
admin-only).

This fixes the KeyError in the decorator by normalizing the args/kwargs
list into a single dict that we can pull the instance from.

Also adds a warning log if we fail the instance update since it
shouldn't happen and we want to know if it does because of the
aforementioned problems with deleting orphaned instances.

There isn't a specific unit test added for this since moving
kwargs['instance'] above the try/except in reverts_task_state makes a
lot of tests fail already if you don't have the normalize code.

Closes-Bug: #1423952

Change-Id: I70f464120c798422f9a3d601b7cdf3b0a8320690

subject: Wait for keystone to be fully initialized
commit_message:
Wait for keystone to be fully initialized

Previously we used check_for_keystone() which just checked that the
keystone v2.0 public endpoint was responding to a http GET. Instead we
now check that making an admin-level request via the keystone client
works correctly. This ensures that the admin tenant and admin role all
exist before proceeding with the rest of the script. Doing so
guarantees that we don't run into a race condition that can occur if
you are starting up multiple containers simultaneously. The problem
can arise if you make two concurrent calls to crux user-create that
both potentially try to create the admin role and tenant. For example
the call in this script and another in keystone/start.sh. See Bug
1429104 for more details.

We could immediately bail out of this script if the new keystone check
fails and stop the container from starting. However I preferred not to
do this and use the wait_for script because it seemed a little more
elegant and also I thought it could result in a faster start up time
e.g. waiting 1sec to check keystone again maybe faster than tearing
down the container and starting it back up again and may generate
less churn in the container logs.

wait_for is a script I gratuitously stole from
openstack/tripleo-incubator/tree/master/scripts. The tripleo team don't
believe in doing releases from that repo, so other than a git checkout
of master there really isn't a nice cross distro way to consume it. If
we think the script could be useful elsewhere then maybe it could
eventually be moved into ./base container

subject: Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service
commit_message:
Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service

Filter scheduler relies on volume services to report their stats in
order to make decisions - this nature makes scheduler service a bit
special when it starts because it can't really do anything without
knowning stats of avilable volume backend.  So the original
implementation of Filter Scheduler added a hook in init_host() to
ask all volume services to send their stats immediately (volume RPC
call 'publish_service_capabitlies()'), this reduced the chance of a
new volume being set to 'error' state because scheduler has no
knowledge of backends to minimum.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | RPC init                          |
              | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |     <-------------  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)

However, commit 65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419 moved
init_host() ahead of service RPC initialization because for volume
services, service initialization should be done before the service
starts accepting RPC requests.  This change unfortunately invalidated
scheduler service's init_host() because that needs to be done *AFTER*
RPC is ready (a queue is bound to scheduler fanout exchange).  The
result is scheduler asks vol service to send update, but it misses
the information it asked for because its queue hasn't been created
and bound to the fanout queue yet.  So scheduler always has to wait
for the next update from volume services to be able to work properly.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |   (vol stats lost)  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)
              | RPC init                          |

This change adds a new hook to Manager class called init_hook_with_rpc()
to allow services like scheduler to do something once RPC is ready.
This should restore scheduler's behavior before commit
65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419.

Change-Id: If6cf9030eb44c39a06ec501ac5c049d460782481
Partial-bug: #1409012
